questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the physician by his friend because of a recent change in his behavior. The friend says that the patient has stopped attending his college classes and started acting in a “bizarre way” over the last eight months. The friend adds that he frequently sees the patient talking to people who are not there. When the physician asks the patient how he is doing, he answers, “The climate is poor, and prices of products are not in the range of people’s ability to purchase in the supermarket.” When asked how he is doing at school, the patient answers, “Not complaining about the economy or the government, but the society needs to be met with more effort.“ Throughout the encounter, the patient makes poor eye contact with the physician. Which of the following is the best description of the language abnormality in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s answers to the questions asked by the physician are completely unrelated to the questions asked, and the sentences themselves do not have any meaning. This speech pattern is known as incoherent speech, sometimes also referred to as a word salad. In addition, the patient appears to be experiencing hallucinations (his friend says they find him talking to non-existent people) and impaired functioning  (no longer attends university classes). These features are suggestive of a diagnosis of schizophrenia.

Language disorder is one of the features of schizophrenia, although it is not seen in all patients. Patients with impaired verbal communication are said to have disorganized thoughts, because the disorganized language reflects their underlying thought disorder. Therefore, the thought disorder is assessed and examined through the patient’s language output.

Disorganized thoughts can be divided into positive and negative thought disorders. Negative thought disorders are seen in presentations such as alogia, which describes poverty of speech; negative thought disorders tend to be seen in patients expressing other negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

On the other hand, positive thought disorders tend to occur more commonly in patients with other positive symptoms (e.g. delusions). Positive thought disorders reflect a language expression that is difficult to understand or follow. The first example is derailment (loosening of association), a pattern of spontaneous speech in which the patient jumps from one topic to a completely (or partly) unrelated topic, and they thus have difficulty expressing their ideas. Derailment reflects frequent interruptions in the thoughts of the patient. An additional presentation of a positive thought disorder is tangential speech. In this language disorder, the patient responds to the questions completely irrelevantly, and the answer is usually not related to the question. In more severe cases, patients with schizophrenia may have incoherent or unintelligible speech (“word salad”), wherein the patient’s words or sentences do not produce any logical meaning.  

Option Analysis

✅ Incoherent speech:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Circumstantial speech:
Incorrect: Circumstantial speech is defined as circuitous and non-direct thoughts that digress from the main point. An individual that displays this characteristic includes unnecessary and extraneous information which, although sometimes relevant, distracts from the central theme or main point of a conversation.  
❌ Clanging:
Incorrect: Clanging refers to speech characterized by associating words based upon sound rather than concepts. For example, this may include rhyming or alliteration without an apparent logical connection between words.  
❌ Word approximations:
Incorrect: Word approximations are real words used in new, unconventional ways. For example, patients demonstrating word approximations may refer to ballpoint pens as “paper skates” or the stomach as a “food vessel.”  
❌ Alogia:
Incorrect: Alogia is a poverty of speech or diminished speech which is seen mostly in patients with other negative symptoms of schizophrenia. Patients tend to answer questions with concise answers (one to two words), answering only the question without providing any additional information beyond the bare minimum. It is typically difficult to carry on a conversation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the physician by his parents due to abnormal behavior. The family tells the physician that their son has been acting strangely over the past eight months. He sometimes appears to be talking to people who are not there and responds to voices that no one in the room can hear. The patient tells the physician that he hears voices telling him about his family and his life. He adds that these voices have told him to do “bad things” to his family, but he refuses because he loves his family. Additionally, the family states that he has been accusing them of working with the government to insert a chip in his brain. The patient currently refuses to eat food cooked by his parents because he thinks they may have inserted the chip in his food. One year ago, he dropped out of college due to declining grades and poor performance. Past medical history is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiology of this patient’s auditory hallucinations?

choices.text: Increased dopaminergic activity in the mesolimbic pathway
Decreased dopaminergic activity in the mesocortical pathway
Decreased dopamine levels in the tuberoinfundibular pathway
Decreased dopamine levels in the nigrostriatal pathway
Decreased dopaminergic activity in the mesolimbic pathway

questions.solution:
This patient has been experiencing auditory hallucinations and delusions for more than 6 months, suggesting a diagnosis of schizophrenia.

The pathophysiology of schizophrenia is thought to be partly due to abnormalities in the neurotransmitters in the brain. In particular, schizophrenia is thought to be caused by abnormalities in dopamine neurotransmission, specifically abnormalities in the D2 receptor's activity. Understanding the four dopamine pathways in the brain is critical to understanding the pathophysiology of schizophrenia and its treatment: the mesolimbic pathway, the mesocortical pathway, the tuberoinfundibular pathway, and the nigrostriatal pathway (as illustrated in the graphic below).
   
  • The mesolimbic pathway extends from the ventral tegmental nucleus (VTA) to the limbic system. Increased dopaminergic activity of this pathway is associated with the positive symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., hallucinations, delusions).  
 
  • The mesocortical pathway: This pathway extends from the VTA to the cortex. Decreased dopaminergic activity of this pathway is associated with the negative symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., anhedonia, poverty of speech, lack of motivation). 
 
  • The tuberoinfundibular pathway: This pathway projects from the hypothalamus to the pituitary gland. Decreased dopaminergic activity in this pathway is associated with increased prolactin levels – leading to galactorrhea, gynecomastia, and infertility. This pathway is responsible for these classic symptoms seen in patients with schizophrenia who are taking antipsychotics (i.e. dopaminergic antagonists).  
 
  • The nigrostriatal pathway: This pathway projects from the substantia nigra to the caudate nucleus. This pathway is connected to the extrapyramidal system, and thus decreased dopaminergic activity in this pathway leads to characteristic motor symptoms (extrapyramidal “Parkinsonian” symptoms) which can be seen in patients with schizophrenia who are taking antipsychotics (i.e. dopaminergic antagonists). 
Additionally, abnormalities in serotonin, glutamate, and GABA neurotransmitters have also been implicated in the neurochemical abnormalities in schizophrenia.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Increased dopaminergic activity in the mesolimbic pathway:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased dopaminergic activity in the mesocortical pathway:
Incorrect: Decreased activity of the mesocortical pathway leads to the negative symptoms seen in schizophrenia. Positive symptoms, as seen in this patient (e.g., hallucinations, delusions), are due to increased dopamine levels in the mesolimbic pathway.  
❌ Decreased dopamine levels in the tuberoinfundibular pathway:
Incorrect: Decreased dopamine activity in the tuberoinfundibular pathway leads to increased prolactin levels, which results in galactorrhea, decreased libido, and gynecomastia. While antipsychotic medications used to treat schizophrenia may cause elevated prolactin levels via this pathway, this patient’s positive schizophrenia symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions) are instead related to increased dopamine levels in the mesolimbic pathway.  
❌ Decreased dopamine levels in the nigrostriatal pathway:
Incorrect: Decreased dopamine levels in the nigrostriatal pathway lead to extrapyramidal symptoms like Parkinsonian symptoms. This patient’s positive schizophrenia symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions) are instead related to increased dopamine levels in the mesolimbic pathway.  
❌ Decreased dopaminergic activity in the mesolimbic pathway:
Incorrect: It is increased dopaminergic activity in the mesolimbic pathway which leads to the positive symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., hallucinations, delusions), not decreased.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual physical. She has been mostly healthy, though she had a fever and dry cough for about one week earlier this year. She tells the physician that her colleagues at work “jinxed me for my good health and wellbeing.” She adds that these colleagues are jealous of her success and wish her bad luck, but she does not believe they intend to cause physical harm. She says that she has a “special ability” to know if someone likes her or not, so she typically carries an array of crystals with her to “ward off evil thoughts.” She has not been hearing voices, and she describes her mood as “fair enough.” The patient has been living on her own for the past 20 years and rarely goes out to new places. She does not use alcohol or recreational drugs. Physical examination shows a middle-aged woman wearing undergarments outside of multiple layers of mismatched clothing. On mental status examination, the patient has a flat affect and avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of magical thinking (i.e., the “unique ability” to know if someone likes her or not, carrying crystals to “ward off evil thoughts”), an odd appearance (multiple layers of mismatched clothes), social isolation, and paranoid ideations; together, these findings are consistent with the diagnosis of schizotypal personality disorder.

Schizotypal personality disorder is a personality disorder characterized by eccentric behavior and odd beliefs with deficiencies in interpersonal relationships. The abnormalities seen in schizotypal personality disorder are in three main domains:

  • Cognitive/perceptual: odd beliefs or magical thinking, unusual experiences or bodily illusions, ideas of reference (i.e. false beliefs that random or irrelevant occurrences in the world are directly related to the individual), odd speech, and paranoid ideation.
  • Oddness/disorganized: Odd appearance, restricted speech, odd behavior.
  • Interpersonal: Lack of close friends, excessive social anxiety that does not diminish with familiarity and is associated with paranoid fears.
Schizotypal personality disorder is considered an intermediate schizophrenia-spectrum phenotype. It has been shown that patients with schizotypal personality disorder (and their family members) are statistically more likely to develop true schizophrenia. Therefore, this personality disorder is thought to represent a subthreshold for psychosis and psychotic disorders like schizophrenia.

Because of the similarities in symptoms, schizotypal personality disorder is frequently misdiagnosed as true schizophrenia. However, it is important to note that in schizotypal personality disorder, the magical thinking and paranoia are not delusional – in other words, the patient does not hold fixed delusions, and they also do not experience hallucinations, unlike patients with schizophrenia.


Option Analysis

✅ Schizotypal personality disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Schizophrenia:
Incorrect: This patient does not have fixed delusions or hallucinations, making the diagnosis of schizophrenia unlikely.  
❌ Schizoaffective disorder:
Incorrect: This patient does not have fixed delusions or hallucinations, which are required for the diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder, and she has not been experiencing major mood symptoms.  
❌ Paranoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: Although this patient does have some paranoid ideations, the additional findings of magical thinking and an odd appearance makes the diagnosis of schizotypal personality disorder more appropriate.  
❌ Schizoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: While social isolation is a feature of schizoid personality disorder, it is also seen in schizotypal personality disorder. In this case, the additional findings of magical thinking and an odd appearance makes the diagnosis of schizotypal personality disorder more appropriate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her parent. For the last three months, the patient has been telling her parent that a famous singer is in love with her and is trying to reach out to her through the lyrics of his songs. The patient tells the physician that she knows he is in love with her and is trying to divorce his wife before officially getting in touch with her – therefore, to avoid any legal consequences, he has to contact her through his songs. Although her family has tried to convince her otherwise, the patient has been extremely stubborn about this belief, and she says that he will marry her as soon as he divorces his wife. The patient is working as a secretary for a law firm and is doing well in her job. She enjoys spending time with her friends and cooking during family gatherings. She does not use alcohol or recreational drugs. A urine drug test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a fixed, false belief of a public figure being in love with her, and apart from this, she has no other symptoms and is functioning normally. Therefore, the most appropriate diagnosis for this patient is delusional disorder.

A delusion is a fixed, false belief that a patient holds against all evidence; the belief must also not be considered normal in the patient’s culture or religion. Delusional disorder is a rare mental disorder characterized by isolated fixed delusions lasting for more than one month. The delusions experienced by patients with delusional disorder are usually well-formed and non-bizarre (i.e. beliefs of something occurring in a person's life which is not technically out of the realm of possibility). These delusions can be of any type, including:
  • Erotomanic: in which the patient believes that someone else—most commonly an authority figure or a celebrity—is in love with them.  
  • Jealous: in which the patient believes their romantic partner is unfaithful, despite the lack of any evidence. 
  • Grandiose: in which the patient believes they have a great talent or knowledge/discovery, paired with an inflated sense of self-worth. 
  • Somatic: in which the patient holds fixed, false beliefs about their bodily functions or sensations. 
  • Persecutory: in which the patient believes they are the victim of a conspiracy or that they are being attacked, harassed, or obstructed.  
In delusional disorder, patients hold one or more delusions and usually have no insight into them. However, apart from the delusions, patients with delusional disorder have no other symptoms and have normal functioning in their social and interpersonal relationships. The DSM-V criteria for delusional disorder are as follows:
  • Patient holds one (or more) delusions for more than one month.  
  • Criteria for schizophrenia are never met  
    •  Note: hallucinations, if present, are not prominent and are directly linked to the patient’s specific delusions. 
  • Apart from delusions and their impact, the patient's functionality is not markedly impaired. Their behavior is not odd or bizarre. 
  • The disturbances are not due to the effect of a substance (e.g. cocaine) or another medical condition. 


Option Analysis

✅ Delusional disorder  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Schizophrenia:
Incorrect: Schizophrenia is a mental illness characterized by a variety of psychotic symptoms and impaired functioning in the patient. This patient has only one psychotic symptom (delusions) and is otherwise functioning well, making delusional disorder the more likely diagnosis.  
❌ Brief psychotic disorder:
Incorrect: Brief psychotic disorder is a transient mental disorder characterized by the presence of psychotic symptoms for less than one month followed by complete remission. This patient’s delusions have been occurring for more than one month.  
❌ Schizophreniform disorder:
Incorrect: Schizophreniform disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms lasting for more than one month but less than six months. While this patient has been experiencing this delusion for three months, there must be more than one psychotic symptom to diagnose schizophreniform disorder. Therefore, delusional disorder is a more appropriate diagnosis for this patient.  
❌ Schizoaffective disorder:
Incorrect: Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by an admixture of psychotic and mood episodes (manic or depressive episodes). This patient does not have any major mood symptoms.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the physician because his partner is worried about the recent odd thoughts he has been having. The partner tells the physician that the patient has refused to eat food they cooked for him for the last seven months because he believes that they are working with the government to try to poison him. The patient tells the physician that he knows that the government is trying to poison him to get rid of him because he “knows too much about them.” He adds that he thinks his partner may be trying to work with them and help poison him, which has required him to be “extra cautious.” Which of the following types of delusions does this patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
Delusions are defined as a distorted way of thinking where an individual holds false, fixed beliefs, usually against the patient's social or religious backgrounds. Delusions can be seen in many psychiatric disorders; for example, they can be seen in isolation in delusional disorders, and they can be seen in conjunction with other symptoms in schizophrenia and schizophreniform disorders.

There are multiple types of delusions, and all are separated according to the type of belief held by the patient. The types of delusions are:
  • Persecutory delusions: An individual believes they have been a victim of a conspiracy or that they are being attacked, harassed, or poisoned. For example, the patient in this vignette has persecutory delusions that the government is trying to poison him because of a long-term agenda.  
  • Erotomanic delusions: An individual believes that another individual (usually a public figure/celebrity) is in love with them. For example, a patient may believe that a particular singer or celebrity whom they have never met is in love with them and is trying to connect with them. 
  • Grandiose delusions: An individual holds unrealistic beliefs of their greatness, such as a great talent, power, or knowledge. For example, a patient may believe that they are a messenger sent to save a group of people from evil.   
  • Jealous delusions: An individual holds fixed beliefs that their partner is unfaithful. This delusion commonly presents as a patient who accuses their partner of cheating, despite having no solid background or evidence for their beliefs. Patients tend to strongly believe that their partner has been unfaithful, and they cannot be convinced otherwise. 
  • Somatic delusions: An individual has fixed false beliefs that their bodily function or appearance is grossly abnormal. For example, a patient with intermittent, idiopathic body aches may believe that they have been infected with a particular parasite and that their internal organs are being consumed by this parasite, despite a negative diagnostic workup.  
  • Mixed delusions: Patients with mixed delusions have two or more types of delusions; for example, a patient may have both jealous and persecutory delusions. 

Option Analysis

✅ Persecutory delusions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Delusional jealousy:
Incorrect: Delusional jealousy is a type of delusion in which an individual has a delusional belief that their romantic partner is being unfaithful.  
❌ Grandiose delusions:
Incorrect: In grandiose delusions, individuals feel that they possess great talents or power or have an extraordinary ability. These patients usually have an inflated self-worth.  
❌ Erotomanic delusions:
Incorrect: In erotomanic delusions, individuals often believe that someone is in love with them, often a celebrity or a public figure.  
❌ Somatic delusions:
Incorrect: Somatic delusions involve false beliefs about their bodily functions or appearance.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the physician by his partner. The partner tells the physician that for the last six months, the patient has been acting like he is responding to voices, and they often hear him muttering as if to someone in the room, even if no one else is present. The patient tells the physician that he hears people talking to him and commanding him to harm himself. However, he has never attempted to do so. Additionally, the patient’s partner notes that he has been accusing the landscaper of “working with the government,” claiming the landscaper is trying to harm him. The partner adds that the patient has become increasingly withdrawn from his friends for the last year. He also stopped visiting family and, five months ago, quit his job for no specific reason. Past medical history is insignificant. The patient has a past history of alcohol use disorder. He used intranasal cocaine on several occasions during college. However, he no longer drinks alcohol and stopped using cocaine three years ago. Urine toxicology is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is having auditory hallucinations, delusions (e.g. thinking the landscaper is trying to harm him), and impaired functionality (e.g., leaving his job, not hanging out with his friends, not visiting family). These symptoms have been present for more than six months, making schizophrenia the most likely diagnosis.

Schizophrenia is a chronic disorder characterized by symptoms that disrupt the patient’s thinking and affect. The psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia are categorized as positive, negative, and cognitive symptoms. Positive symptoms include delusions and hallucinations. Negative symptoms include anhedonia, alogia (poverty of speech), avolition (decreased goal-directed activity), and diminished emotional expression. Finally, the cognitive symptoms include disorganized speech or thoughts that ultimately impair the patient’s ability to function.

Patients with schizophrenia usually have a prodromal period that precedes the first psychotic symptoms, during which the patient has impairment in their functionality, social withdrawal, or decreased self-care. The first psychotic episode (positive and/or negative) usually follows this prodromal period, initiating the active phase. However, some patients do not have a clear prodromal period and may begin with psychotic symptoms immediately. Later, the residual phase is predominantly characterized by worsening cognitive symptoms.

The DSM-V criteria for the diagnosis of schizophrenia are as follows:
   
  •  Presence of ≥ 2 or more of the following active phase symptoms, each lasting at least one month:  
    •  Delusions 
    •  Hallucinations 
    •  Disorganized speech  
    •  Disorganized or catatonic behavior  
    •  Negative symptoms 
  •  At least one of the two symptoms must be from the first 3 (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech).  
  •  Social and occupational dysfunction in one or more major areas such as work, social relationships, self-care. 
  •  The signs of disturbances are present for at least six months, which may include the prodromal phase, the active symptoms, and the residual phase. During this period, the patient exhibits active symptoms for at least one month.  
  •  The symptoms are not due to or better explained by another mental condition, such as major depression or bipolar disorder with psychotic features. 
  •  The symptoms are not due to or better explained by substance use.


Option Analysis

✅ Schizophrenia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Delusional disorder  :
Incorrect: Patients with delusional disorder exhibit isolated delusions without hallucinations or impaired functionality outside the frame of the delusions, unlike this patient.  
❌ Substance-induced psychosis:
Incorrect: This patient has a past history of alcohol and cocaine use in the past. However, he states he is no longer using these substances, which is further validated by the negative urine toxicology.  
❌ Schizotypal personality disorder:
Incorrect: Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by odd behavior and eccentric thinking. However, true psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations) are not seen. Additionally, the characteristic behaviors and traits associated with personality disorders are more consistent, with a typical onset in middle to late adolescence and continuing into adult life. This patient’s symptoms started one year ago, making a diagnosis of a personality disorder unlikely.  
❌ Paranoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with paranoid personality disorder are generally suspicious of their surroundings and may accuse their romantic partners of being unfaithful. However, these patients do not have specific delusions like this patient (e.g. thinking the landscaper is trying to harm him), and they do not have hallucinations. Additionally, the characteristic behaviors and traits associated with personality disorders are more consistent, with a typical onset in middle to late adolescence and continuing into adult life. This patient’s symptoms started one year ago, making a diagnosis of a personality disorder unlikely.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman and her 20-year-old son are brought to the physician by the woman’s sister. For the last two years, the mother has been accusing her neighbors of using black magic on her and her son to harm them. She has frequently gotten into verbal fights with them, and she has cut off all social contact with anyone in the neighborhood. She currently tries to avoid going outside her house to avoid contact with them. The son tells the physician that he recently started to understand that his neighbors will indeed harm them with black magic if they aren’t careful, and he has entered into verbal and physical altercations to protect himself and his mother “against their dark powers.” Over the past two months, he has spent most of his time in the house with his mother. In the office, the mother is poorly-groomed, irritable, and appears to be listening and responding to voices. The son is also irritable and becomes agitated when asked further questions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Shared psychotic disorder (also called folie à deux) describes a mental illness in which the psychotic symptoms are identical between two or more close individuals. In shared psychotic disorder, psychotic symptoms (usually paranoid delusions) are transferred to another person with whom the patient has an intimate relationship so that both individuals come to share the same delusional thoughts.

In most cases of shared psychotic disorder, the two people sharing the delusions live together. The inducer is usually the more dominant person in the relationship and initially acquires the delusions, provoking the more submissive person (the induced) into accepting the beliefs. Most of the time, the inducer has an underlying mental illness, while a mental disorder is not a prerequisite in the induced. As time goes on, these patients tend to believe and support each other’s delusions.

The most important step in treatment of shared psychotic disorder is separation to break the chain of reinforcement of the delusions. Separation also helps identify if the inducer and induced both have a mental illness or if the induced has no underlying disorders and was forced to believe the induced delusions unconsciously. In addition to separation, treatment with medications is also often necessary.

Option Analysis

✅ Shared psychotic disorder  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Paranoid personality disorder:
Incorrect: Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by paranoid delusions, a pervasive, long-standing suspiciousness, and generalized mistrust of others. Although this woman is suspicious of her neighbors, she also has persistent delusions and hallucinations, making an underlying psychotic disorder the more likely cause.  
❌ Schizoaffective disorder  :
Incorrect: In schizoaffective disorder, mood episodes (depressive or manic episodes) must be present. Neither the son nor the mother have major mood symptoms.  
❌ Depressed mood with psychotic features  :
Incorrect: Patients with severe depression can sometimes develop psychotic symptoms. However, neither of these patients meet the criteria for depression.  
❌ Adjustment disorder  :
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder cannot be diagnosed if the patient meets the criteria for another diagnosis (in this case, a diagnosis of shared psychotic disorder).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her spouse due to a depressed mood for the majority of the last two years. The patient agrees and tells the physician that she feels her mood has been particularly low in the last month. She states she is often fatigued and cannot seem to concentrate on small tasks, such as following conversations. She also finds it difficult to fall asleep at night. The patient’s spouse adds that her appetite seems poor, and she often leaves food untouched at meals. The patient tells the physician that she is hearing voices telling her that this is the punishment she deserves. The voices have also told her to harm herself and have told her that her spouse is planning to poison her. About 18 months ago, the patient was hearing voices telling her to harm herself for a period of three weeks, but she did not have depressive symptoms at that time. She is not currently taking any medications. She does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.solution:
This patient currently meets the criteria for major depressive disorder, and she has had a depressed mood for most of the last two years. In addition, she is currently experiencing psychotic symptoms, and she has a history of 3 weeks of psychotic symptoms without any mood symptoms. Given this combination of symptoms, this patient’s most likely diagnosis is schizoaffective disorder.

Schizoaffective disorder is a chronic mental disorder in which patients have an admixture of mood symptoms and psychotic symptoms. The condition is characterized by mood episodes (manic or depressive episodes) alongside psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech). The diagnostic criteria for schizoaffective disorder are as follows:
   
  • An uninterrupted period of illness during which there is a major mood episode (major depressive or manic episode) concurrent with criterion A of schizophrenia. Criterion A for schizophrenia is the presence of two or more of the following five symptoms for at least one month (at least one symptom from the first three):  
    •  1. Delusions  
    •  2. Hallucinations 
    •  3. Disorganized speech 
    •  4. Disorganized or catatonic behavior 
    •  5. Negative symptoms (e.g., anhedonia, alogia, avolition) 
 
  • Delusions or hallucinations for two or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode (major depressive or manic episode) during the disease duration.  
 
  • Symptoms that meet the criteria for a major mood episode are present for the majority of the total duration of the illness. 
 
  • The disturbances are not due to substance use or another medical condition.  
Schizoaffective disorder is commonly misdiagnosed due to its similarities with other conditions. For instance, mood disorders with psychotic features can be difficult to differentiate from schizoaffective disorders. However, in mood disorders with psychotic features, the psychotic features (e.g., hallucinations, delusions) occur exclusively during the mood episodes (major depressive or manic episodes). By comparison, in patients with schizoaffective disorder, psychotic symptoms must occur for at least two weeks independent of any other major mood symptoms. Meanwhile, schizophrenia can be distinguished from schizoaffective disorder by the fact that schizophrenia does not cause major mood symptoms during the active phase of psychotic symptoms.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Schizoaffective disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Major depressive disorder with psychotic features:
Incorrect: This patient meets the criteria for MDD, and the psychotic symptoms she is experiencing could accompany depression in some patients. However, she also has a history of a 3-week episode where she was experiencing psychotic symptoms without any mood symptoms, making the schizoaffective disorder the more likely diagnosis.  
❌ Schizophrenia:
Incorrect: This patient does have psychotic symptoms seen in schizophrenia. However, she has also experienced significant mood symptoms and currently meets the criteria for major depressive disorder. This combination of psychotic and mood symptoms makes the diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder more appropriate.  
❌ Schizophreniform disorder:
Incorrect: Schizophreniform disorder is similar to schizophrenia, but the duration of symptoms is less than six months. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with schizoaffective disorder.  
❌ Adjustment disorder:
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder cannot be diagnosed if a patient meets the criteria for another diagnosis. This patient meets the criteria for a diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the physician by his parent due to concerns of abnormal behavior. The patient’s parent tells the physician that the patient has been acting in a strange manner lately. Eight months ago, he spontaneously left his job, which he previously enjoyed, without reason. The parent adds that he no longer spends time with his friends and has become increasingly withdrawn from his family. Last month, he started acting as if he was responding to a voice no one else could hear, and he has been heard talking to himself in his room. The patient tells the physician that someone is talking to him and telling him about plans related to people trying to harm him. The patient recreationally uses alcohol and cocaine. He has also smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the last five years. He was diagnosed with migraines three years ago but has not experienced any headaches recently. According to the patient’s parent, there is no known history of mental health disorders in the family. The physician strongly suspects a diagnosis of schizophrenia. Which of the following is considered a risk factor for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Schizophrenia is a chronic mental condition characterized by a fragmented pattern of thinking which manifests with an array of symptoms. Schizophrenia affects 1% of the population globally, although the prevalence widely varies in different groups. For example, schizophrenia is slightly more common in males than females, and the onset in males is typically earlier than that in females.

Although schizophrenia most likely occurs spontaneously, certain risk factors may be present. Such risk factors include a family history of schizophrenia, birth complications (e.g., preeclampsia, toxin exposure in utero), childhood trauma, social isolation, and severe malnutrition. In addition, the use of cannabis is associated with an increased risk of schizophrenia, and it is currently the only substance that is linked to the development of this disorder.

Schizophrenia has a wide array of symptoms, and patients may develop some or all of these symptoms. The symptoms of schizophrenia are subcategorized into different entities:
  
  •  Positive symptoms: These symptoms represent symptoms that are not found in a healthy individual but are found in a patient with schizophrenia. These symptoms include delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, disorganized behavior, and catatonic behavior.  
  •  Negative symptoms: These symptoms represent the removal of normal processes like emotions and interest. Therefore, these symptoms include anhedonia, poverty of speech, and lack of motivation. 
  •  Cognitive symptoms: These symptoms may be the hardest to notice in patients with schizophrenia. Here, memory, understanding, and learning are affected. Manifestations may include not being able to understand others or not being able to keep track of several things at once. Cognitive impairment is considered a poor prognostic factor in schizophrenia.  
Schizophrenia is associated with many complications. It may lead to impairment of the overall functionality of the patient, impairing their social and economic functioning, leading to financial and social challenges and eventually a poor quality of life. The degree of functional impairment can be mitigated with appropriate treatment, though some patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia may experience significant functional impairment despite medical intervention. In addition, patients with schizophrenia are more likely to develop anxiety, substance use disorders, and depression. Suicide rates are higher in patients with schizophrenia. Lastly, patients with schizophrenia are at a significantly increased risk of becoming victims of violence and other abuse, and healthcare providers should screen patients accordingly.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

 
 

Option Analysis

❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: Tobacco use is not a risk factor for the development of schizophrenia. However, it is important to note that patients with schizophrenia are at increased risk of developing other comorbidities, including substance use disorders and depression.  
✅ Male sex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Alcohol use:
Incorrect: Alcohol use is not a risk factor for the development of schizophrenia. However, it is important to note that patients with schizophrenia are at increased risk of developing other comorbidities, including substance use disorders and depression.  
❌ Cocaine use:
Incorrect: Cocaine use is not a risk factor for the development of schizophrenia. However, it is important to note that patients with schizophrenia are at increased risk of developing other comorbidities, including substance use disorders and depression.  
❌ Migraine headache:
Incorrect: Migraine headaches are not associated with an increased risk of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the physician by his parent due to hallucinations. For the past 8 months, the patient has been hearing voices of people speaking directly to him. The patient tells the physician that these voices typically tell him to do different things and are occasionally threatening to him, telling him to harm himself. He additionally believes that the government is trying to “get rid of him” because he may have exposed their plans in destroying the climate. He stopped going to work as a cashier five months ago and is currently living with his parent. She tells the physician that her son refuses to eat and shower sometimes. He does not use any recreational drugs and does not drink alcohol. The physician decides to prescribe the patient haloperidol to treat his condition. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which haloperidol helps in alleviating this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Blocking dopamine receptors in the mesolimbic pathway
Blocking dopamine receptors in the mesocortical pathway
Blocking serotonin receptors in the mesocortical pathway
Blocking dopamine receptors in the nigrostriatal pathway
Blocking dopamine receptors in the tuberoinfundibular pathway

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hallucinations, delusions, and various negative symptoms (e.g., social withdrawal, poor self-hygiene); he most likely has schizophrenia. The treatment of schizophrenia is complex, and the main aim is to reduce symptoms, prevent relapses, and improve the functionality of the patient in society. The treatment of schizophrenia has many aspects, including pharmacological treatment and psychotherapy.

Pharmacological treatment with antipsychotics is the cornerstone of the treatment of schizophrenia. Understanding the mechanism of action of antipsychotic drugs helps explain their effectiveness in the treatment of schizophrenia.

Typical (or “first-generation”) antipsychotic medications (such as the haloperidol prescribed in this case) are dopamine D2 receptor antagonists. Since increased activity and overactivation of D2 receptors in the mesolimbic pathway is the proposed mechanism for the positive symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g., delusions, hallucinations), these drugs are effective against the positive symptoms of schizophrenia.

However, the negative symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g. anhedonia) are thought to be due to decreased activity of dopamine D2 receptors in the mesocortical pathway. This mechanism explains why typical antipsychotics are not very effective in alleviating the negative symptoms of this condition.

Atypical antipsychotics (or “second-generation”) have an additional 5-HT2 serotonin receptor antagonist properties. Blocking 5-HT2 receptors in the mesocortical pathway is thought to stimulate the release of dopamine in this pathway, which explains why atypical antipsychotic drugs are more effective than typical antipsychotics in treating the negative symptoms of schizophrenia. Atypical antipsychotics are still effective in alleviating the positive symptoms by blocking the D2 receptors in the mesolimbic pathway – they simply add the benefit of alleviating the negative symptoms by blocking the 5HT2 receptors in the mesocortical pathway. In addition, atypical antipsychotics have fewer extrapyramidal side effects. For this reason, atypical antipsychotics are considered the first-line treatment for schizophrenia.

Option Analysis

✅ Blocking dopamine receptors in the mesolimbic pathway:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blocking dopamine receptors in the mesocortical pathway:
Incorrect: Decreased activity of the dopamine receptors in the mesocortical pathway is associated with negative symptoms of schizophrenia. This pathophysiology explains the lower efficacy of dopamine antagonists (e.g. haloperidol) in alleviating the negative symptoms of schizophrenia.  
❌ Blocking serotonin receptors in the mesocortical pathway:
Incorrect: Second generation antipsychotics have 5-HT2 antagonist properties, in addition to the dopamine antagonist properties. Blocking 5-HT2 receptors in the mesocortical pathway is thought to stimulate the release of dopamine in this pathway, which helps alleviate the negative symptoms of schizophrenia. However, first-generation antipsychotics (e.g. haloperidol) do not have 5-HT2 receptor antagonist properties.  
❌ Blocking dopamine receptors in the nigrostriatal pathway:
Incorrect: The nigrostriatal pathway is involved in coordinating movement and is mediated by dopamine. Blocking dopamine receptors in this pathway results in the extrapyramidal side effects (e.g., dystonia, akathisia, tardive dyskinesia) seen in patients taking dopamine antagonists.  
❌ Blocking dopamine receptors in the tuberoinfundibular pathway:
Incorrect: Blocking dopamine receptors in the tuberoinfundibular pathway results in increased release of prolactin, causing the side effects of gynecomastia, decreased libido, and infertility in patients taking dopamine antagonists.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the physician by his partner to evaluate an unpleasant feeling on his skin. The patient tells the physician that he feels like “bugs are climbing all over my skin.” This sensation is deeply distressing to the patient, and he is constantly trying to scratch his skin, even at bedtime, often disrupting his sleep. He has not experienced visual or auditory hallucinations. His partner is also concerned because the patient has lost 25-lb over the past six months. The patient has no history of mental disorders or any other diseases. The partner denies experiencing a similar sensation and has no difficulty sleeping at night. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 160/94 mmHg. Physical examination of the patient reveals evidence of skin picking and bruises on the skin, most prominent on the forearms and antecubital region. In addition, the nose appears dry with some residual blood. The patient is easily irritated when asked questions throughout the encounter. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has abnormal sensations on his skin with no tactile stimulation; these false perceptions are tactile hallucinations. In addition, he has high blood pressure and tachycardia, dry nostrils with crusted blood, extremity bruising, weight loss, and irritability. This presentation is most likely due to underlying substance use disorder, most likely from intranasal and intravenous cocaine use.

Hallucinations are sensory perceptions without an external stimulus, meaning that the patient feels sensations that are not there. Although hallucinations are most commonly associated with schizophreniform disorders, they can occur in other pathological diseases such as substance use or delirium. Hallucinations are divided according to the type of abnormal sensations. The type of hallucination can be a clue to the cause:

  • Auditory hallucinations: Auditory hallucinations are the experience of hearing things that are not there, such as voices, commands, or even conversations. Sometimes the voices directly contact the patient, while in other cases, the patient may feel as though they are listening to a conversation. Auditory hallucinations can be severely distressing to the patient and their community, especially if it involves commanding, threatening, or haunting voices; they can lead to impairment of the social and occupational functioning of the patient. Auditory hallucinations are the most common type of hallucinations seen in schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders.  

  • Visual hallucinations: Patients with visual hallucinations have visual perceptions of images, objects, or even colors that are not there. Visual hallucinations can happen in various disorders, particularly in psychotic disorders like schizophrenia. Visual hallucinations can also happen in patients with seizure disorders who may have abnormal brain activity involving the visual field in the cerebral cortex (i.e. occipital seizures). Additionally, some patients with brain tumors can have visual hallucinations, most commonly seen in tumors involving the temporal lobe. Finally, visual hallucinations can also be seen in patients with migraines or ophthalmic disorders or in patients using psychoactive drugs.  

  • Tactile hallucinations: In tactile hallucinations, the patient has an abnormal perception of touch or the feeling of movement on their skin or inside their body. This type of hallucination is most commonly seen in patients taking psychoactive substances. For example, “cocaine bug” is a distressing tactile hallucination in patients addicted to cocaine, where these patients falsely feel that bugs are crawling over their skin. Although less commonly, tactile hallucinations can also be seen in psychotic disorders like schizophrenia. 

Option Analysis

✅ Substance use disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Schizophrenia:
Incorrect: Although schizophrenia can be associated with tactile hallucinations, it is more commonly associated with auditory hallucinations. In addition, the patient's physical findings (e.g., elevated blood pressure, tachycardia, epistaxis, antecubital bruising) suggest a substance use disorder as the more likely cause. Schizophrenia cannot be diagnosed if the symptoms can be explained by substance use or a medical condition.  
❌ Delusional disorder:
Incorrect: Delusional disorder is associated with fixed false beliefs. The delusions in this condition are isolated, meaning that they are not associated with any other psychiatric symptom, including hallucinations.  
❌ Bed bugs:
Incorrect: Bed bugs are blood-feeding insects that inhabit human dwellings and may cause skin reactions in humans. Although bed bugs may have explained this patient’s symptoms, this diagnosis is unlikely given his partner's lack of symptoms. Additionally, his other physical findings (e.g., elevated blood pressure, tachycardia, epistaxis, antecubital fossa bruising) suggest another underlying cause.  
❌ Schizoaffective disorder:
Incorrect: Schizoaffective disorder is associated with psychotic symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions) and mood symptoms (e.g., mania, depression). However, this patient’s presentation is more likely due to a substance use disorder rather than schizoaffective disorder, given his associated physical findings (e.g., high blood pressure, tachycardia, epistaxis, antecubital fossa bruising).

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the physician by his family due to concerns about his behavior. The patient’s parent tells the physician that for the past month, the patient has been telling them that he is receiving signals on the television from a secret organization to “save the world from the upcoming alien invasion.” His parent adds that they sometimes see the patient communicating with people who are not there. The patient dropped out of his college courses seven months ago after his grades deteriorated, although he was an excellent student before. At that time, the patient also stopped taking care of his hygiene, often not showering for multiple days, and he has withdrawn from his friends and family. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has been having delusions and hallucinations for one month. In addition, he has experienced significant impairment in his school work and interpersonal relationships for more than 6 months, making schizophrenia the most likely diagnosis.

Brief psychotic disorder, schizophreniform disorder, and schizophrenia are all psychotic disorders with similar symptoms that differ mainly in the duration of the symptoms.

  • Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by transient psychotic symptoms that last less than one month and are followed by a complete remission (though patients may have future relapses). The diagnosis must be made retrospectively because the complete remission within one month must be observed.

  • Schizophreniform disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms that last more than one month but less than six months. This period includes the prodromal phase, active symptoms of psychosis, and residual symptoms. Unlike schizophrenia, impaired functionality is not required to make the diagnosis of schizophreniform disorder.
 
  • In schizophrenia, the duration of symptoms must be more than six months. This period includes the prodromal period (where the patient may not show true psychotic symptoms but rather show impairments in their daily functioning, social withdrawal, or decreased self-care), active symptoms of psychosis (e.g., delusions, hallucinations), and the residual period (characterized by worsening cognitive symptoms). The active symptoms of psychosis must last at least one month, and functional impairment must be present to make the diagnosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Schizophrenia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Brief psychotic disorder:
Incorrect: A brief psychotic disorder is characterized by transient psychotic symptoms for a period of one month followed by complete remission. This patient meets the criteria for diagnosis of schizophrenia as his symptoms have lasted for more than 6 months.  
❌ Delusional disorder:
Incorrect: Delusional disorder is characterized by isolated fixed delusions without any other psychotic symptoms or impaired functionality apart from the context of the delusions. This patient has other psychotic symptoms (hallucinations) and impairment in his functioning, making schizophrenia a more appropriate diagnosis.  
❌ Schizophreniform disorder:
Incorrect: Schizophreniform disorder is a psychotic disorder with the same psychotic symptoms as schizophrenia, but the condition differs in the duration of symptoms. In schizophreniform disorder, psychotic symptoms last for more than one month but less than 6 months. This patient’s symptoms (including the prodromal symptoms) have lasted for more than 6 months, making schizophrenia a more appropriate diagnosis.  
❌ Narcissistic personality disorder:
Incorrect: Narcissistic personality disorder is characterized by an over-exaggeration of self-importance, inflated self-esteem, and lack of empathy. Fixed delusions and hallucinations are not seen in patients with narcissistic personality disorder.
